movie.title: Remember the Sultana
movie.description_intro: The Sultana was a river boat that exploded in 1865 killing many passengers, mostly Union Soldiers.
movie.description_full: The Sultana was a river boat that exploded in 1865 killing many passengers, mostly Union Soldiers.

movies.title: QT8: The First Eight
movies.summary: A documentary that focuses on the first 21 years of Quentin Tarantino's career and includes interviews with his frequent collaborators.
movies.description_full: A documentary that focuses on the first 21 years of Quentin Tarantino's career and includes interviews with his frequent collaborators.
movies.synopsis: A documentary that focuses on the first 21 years of Quentin Tarantino's career and includes interviews with his frequent collaborators.

movies.title: Divide in Concord
movies.summary: This is a story about an 84 year-old-woman trying to take down the third largest industry in the world. Jean Hill, a self-proclaimed warrior, leads historic Concord, Massachusetts on America's first environmental crusade to ban the sale of bottled water.
movies.description_full: This is a story about an 84 year-old-woman trying to take down the third largest industry in the world. Jean Hill, a self-proclaimed warrior, leads historic Concord, Massachusetts on America's first environmental crusade to ban the sale of bottled water.

movies.title: Macho: The Hector Camacho Story
movies.summary: A hard-hitting look at the rise, fall and untimely death of one of boxing's most colorful champions. Hector Camacho's dynamic speed, footwork and power made him a fighter to be reckoned with, but it was his flamboyance and showmanship that ushered in a new era in boxing. The film chronicles his epic battles inside the ring, his struggles with addiction outside of it and the mystery of the double homicide that claimed his life. It's an unflinching portrait of a fighter who transcended the sport but ultimately couldn't defeat his own demons.

movies.title: Field of Operations: Leningrad
movies.summary: The siege began on 8 September 1941, when the Wehrmacht severed the last road to the city. Although Soviet forces managed to open a narrow land corridor to the city on 18 January 1943, the Red Army did not lift the siege until 27 January 1944, 872 days after it began. The blockade became one of the longest and most destructive sieges in history, and it was possibly the costliest siege in history due to the number of casualties which were suffered during it. In the 21st century some historians have classified it as a genocide due to the systematic starvation and intentional destruction of the city's civilian population.
